title: Great place to work!
pros: Good hours, Driving for work, Company vehicle, Overtime.
cons: Other than lifting heavy boxes some days there's not much cons.

title: Former Employee
pros: The company held a lot of appreciation days and provided meals.
cons: In office requirements were changed from once a month to daily which took away from the pay.

title: Turnover is due to Iron Mountain's lust to be a $5B company
pros: Individual teams work well together. Individual teams also work hard to reach goals presented to them. There are good people that work at Iron Mountain.
cons: Higher level management teams trickle down edicts from upper management to cut costs (at all costs) just to reach this $5B goal (publicly stated and released) and to satisfy the investors of Iron Mountain. We heard a lot from the CEO and CFO about where the company stands on EBDIT and where the company stands financially against the $5B goal and EBDIT. To achieve this, the company, along with their outsourced advisory company, have made changes to the company that make it very difficult to work at IRM. In sales, you do not know if you have a position on a month to month basis. Some sales cycles with clients can take months of relationship building before the sales close and used to be the understanding with management at Iron Mountain. Now management wants results monthly regardless of what the sales cycle is. With all other positions, you do not know if you will be employed on a month-to-month basis either as all positions are fair game.

title: Used until you break
pros: Other coworkers tend to be friendly Management team will at least respect you
cons: Inconsistent Hours Inconsistent Work Inconsistent Workload Extremely high expectations, low reward, low benefits Consistent misinformation from the company

title: Great place to work
pros: Professional development: There were opportunities to gain experience with compliance, records management, and secure data handling, which are valuable across industries. Supportive team environment: Many colleagues were collaborative and willing to share knowledge, which helped foster growth and efficiency. Good benefits package: Competitive healthcare, retirement contributions, and paid time off added to overall job security.
cons: Slow pace of change: As a large, established company, new ideas and initiatives often took a long time to gain traction. Limited upward mobility: Career progression could feel constrained unless you were in specific tracks or willing to relocate.

title: Great Managers Horrible Strategy
pros: Remote Supportive teams Supportive Managers You will have many job functions that will help build your resume
cons: Will retroactively revoke bonuses if you're making too much. I earned 24k in renewal bonuses because I convinced customers to renew their contracts at a higher rate. After Iron Mountain realized were paying out alot of bonuses, they sent an email 2 months after the bonus paperwork was submitted and approved stating that they're retroactively ending the program for high earners. Changes Comp plans if you're making too much money. Changed Compensation plans to a structure that starves their Sales reps until they reach have of their yearly quota

title: Great company

title: Upper Management disconnected

cons: Upper Management is completely disconnected from sales and high level executive relationships with some of their biggest customers is non existent

title: Pay is low
pros: Work life balance is nice

title: Laid off entire department without WARN filing.
pros: Immediate 2 levels of management were great.
cons: Higher levels of management were absolute crud. My entire department was laid off by someone who had never shown his face to us, and then offshored.

title: Solid Employer
pros: Competitive pay with advancement opportunities.
cons: Higher than normal turn over.

title: Toxic Work culture
pros: Global exposure, Remote work. Good Insurance benifits
cons: Very toxic work culture. Stubborn managers and leadership with no recognition for any creative work or working overtime to get additional last minute tasks done. Managers are waiting for you to make 1 small mistake to play the blame game even if you do 9/10 things right. Feels like everyone has fit into this mold to keep their position and throw someone else under the bus. For a dinosaur company like iron mountain they sure hire and fire faster than a silicon valley start-up. Even though the company just started unlimited PTO, management makes it utterly difficult to approve even 2-3 day leave requests. Feels like company was forced to implement unlimited PTO to avoid paying a bulk of employees they constantly fire instead of actually benefitting the employee which is how it was presented, but sadly that is not the case. For any employee thinking of join IM, please do your due diligence before leaving your current job.

title: Poor leadership
pros: The employees are generally nice
cons: Leadership is poor and the talent pool is bad. Poor performers are not held accountable

title: Here's to Making it Work
pros: You can look forward to a stable schedule, plenty of overtime opportunities, flexible schedule changes, and leadership that is very accepting of time off when given enough notice. The PTO itself is very easy to track with an online system and onsite clock in device. The leadership is very transparent with company & HIPAA policies, and are easy to ask questions about any task. Additional training on something you do not understand is easy to get.
cons: The starting pay is very low, barely minimum wage to keep up with how costly the times are. The workplace is very physically crowded which fosters gossip, and is probably unsafe for HIPAA policy honestly. The supervisors are transparent, but tend to over complicate tasks, focus on the odd parts of workplace solutions, or don't compromise well with staff making them feel unheard or misunderstood.

title: Great view from the outside, spoiled on the inside.
pros: Decent pay, fast paced, always learning new methods. I always enjoyed how diverse that specific location was.
cons: Constant changes between management, went through 3 managers within the 3 years I was there. They have been laying off agents in the US since 2022 to hire and underpay agents in Colombia and India. Very contradicting, especially knowing the majority of client's have expressed difficulties regarding the extreme delay it takes to get to a US based agent due to the language barrier. It was also hard to explain client's billing concerns when we are able to see the price gauging ourselves as agents. I mean, we're talking about client's rates being increased twice within a 1 year period.

pros: You have a job. You have benefits

title: Do not work here
pros: The people are great, I really do like my teammates
cons: Horrible pay and commission structure. Changes constantly, making it impossible to reach your quota. If you are at 75% or less to goal in the quarter, you're fired. Generates a culture of fear, everyone is afraid of that 1:1 on their calendar, thinking it is their last day. Management promotes sneaky tactics just so they can hit their goal to look good on the dashboard, but you will never be paid on it. Please, do not waste time here, there are other jobs out there that will pay you better and treat you with respect and have a better company culture. No room for promotions - people stuck in the same role for 6+ years with no promotion but management keeps promising them. Iron Mountain is slammed in the BBB, so you also have to deal with angry customers 24/7. Iron Mountain gouges their clients and locks them in contracts they have to pay six figures to get out of.

title: Iron Mountain Review
pros: Good culture among close teams Big company with opportunities to network with other teams and learn about their work
cons: Not enough communication from the upper management Sudden structural changes Upper management does not think about employees Very bad experience during the layoff call - the manager who laid me off didn't even ask how I was feeling.

title: Sales
pros: People were so helpful and the job required lots of mental "thinking on your feet:" when talking with customers to position the company correctly.
cons: Unfortunately a "sales reorganization" occured and apparently happens frequently which I didn't know when I went to work for them.

title: Team Collaboration
pros: The leadership team is approachable and transparent, and they genuinely care about employee well-being. There’s a strong focus on work-life balance, and the flexibility offered—especially in today’s hybrid environment—is a huge plus. Collaboration is part of the culture here, and I’ve had the chance to work cross-functionally with incredibly smart, driven people who are passionate about what they do. The finance and accounting teams are highly respected within the business and play a key role in strategic decision-making, which makes the work feel meaningful.
cons: As with many large organizations, navigating internal processes and layers of approval can be slow at times. It requires patience and persistence to drive change, but strong communication and a proactive mindset go a long way in getting things done.

title: They're not ethical
pros: They pay you on time. Coordinators are reasonable and flexible
cons: Daily quotas You must do unethical things to meet quotas Revenue generating tasks (Rebox / Relid) are unfair to customers Physically exhausting work Workers are unhappy No assigned positions Can be transferred anytime Temporary workers often get paid more than new employees

title: People are nice, but lack of vision seems to hold back progress
pros: There are no shortages of great ideas and products that they want to implement, always striving for looking at the next best thing. Sometimes at the determent of the clients they serve, even though they should be in a better place
cons: Lack of alignment at the leadership levels seems to always get in the way of progress. Needs to find a better way to align on actual strategy

title: Computer Technician Phoenix, Arizona

title: Great company

title: Great job, Great people,
pros: This was a great job. Training was as long as it needed to be. Management wanted you to succeed. Team felt like a family. I miss this job!
cons: No cons at all. Loved it here!

title: Directionless
pros: Experience navigating frequent change and developing resiliency
cons: The company is completely directionless and does not have realistic expectations aligned with their current market position in the SMB or Mid-Market space. You are forced to choose between meeting deadlines for low impact administrative tasks or taking the necessary actions to be effective at your job. The executive leadership team is extremely out of touch and far removed from their front-line employees leading to bottle-necks and inefficiencies in process. There is very little being invested into customer support and as a result, customer satisfaction is at an all time low. There are class action lawsuits and many complaints against the company due to their failing business model forcing 200%+ price increases onto their customer base within 1 to 2 years. Their priority is on scaling their digital solutions lobs while not having a competitive product or solution. Absolutely horrible profit over people culture and sales leadership team that is incapable of inspiring or engaging employees. No budget for incentives to drive competition or motivate representatives. I would describe as the merry-go-round of misery.

title: Changes are becoming impossible to navigate
pros: Huge 70 year legacy of protecting some of the worlds most protected information An attempt for Digital Transformation internally to bring new products and solutions to our customers as we tout how we can help customers with their Digital Transformation Increased global positioning as a leader in the ITAD/ITAM arena
cons: Mass layoffs and a drastic change in compensation indicate it's now profits over people as shareholders seem to be more important The majority of salespeople still don't understand our 2024 compensation plan. Layoffs and resignations are significantly impacting sales opportunities which then impact sales compensations Generic "we listen to what you have to say" on nearly every post on Glassdoor implies no one bothers to even look at this or care

title: Iron Mountain INC
pros: Very rewarding and Challenging work.
cons: You have to make yourself unplug and not get encompassed in work or it will bleed into Work Life Balance.

title: I love working for Iron Mountain
pros: Iron Mountain's biggest asset is its people. I love working with my team and I find the culture at Iron Mountain is the best I have worked in Corporate. No backstabbing or fear from leadership makes you do things that you don't think are right. I find the leadership is very transparent and there is a lot of room for growth in the organization. There are different teams that own their work and there are lot of enablement tools provided to get the work done effectively. I love my work and my team and would highly recommend working at Iron Mountain
cons: Large organization similar to any other company sometimes takes longer to get things across the finish line with many approvals. Another con is there can be budget constraints at times, but that I think comes in every company. Sometimes we work in silos and it be cause duplication of work but for the most part we work well across teams for the most part.

title: Beware of Indian politics at this company
pros: * Benefits are good ( health insurance, dental and vision) * remote friendly * wlb * lots of history
cons: he leadership here is incredibly corrupt, full of bias and internal politics. They have the wrong people in key positions, and the directors clearly have no idea what they’re doing. Talent is constantly overlooked, and the overwhelming number of Indians in leadership roles is destroying what was once a great American company. They’re bringing in toxic politics that are ruining the organization from the inside out. These people need to go if this company ever wants to return to its former glory. The constant internal conflicts and power struggles are leading nowhere. *Interacting with people like this every day can seriously damage your mental health. * I initially thought I was stuck in a toxic team and wanted to switch, only to discover that the same problems exist in other teams as well.

title: Decent company to work for
pros: -Home at the end of the day -Overtime hours available if desired -Easy onboarding process -Relatively easy to request time off -Close-knit driving team -Easy job to pick up -Off on weekends

title: Great company, great pay, solid customer base, ample sales opportunities
pros: Lots of great supportive people who are more customer focused than other tech giants I have worked for. The offer I accepted was higher than I had expected for my experience level (Around $100k base / $100k comm for Enterprise AE role with 10 yrs B2B exp.). Lots of selling tools, a dedicated CSM (vital to your success), a shared SDR, and a shared SME for each major product category. Customers generally like us, are easy to engage with and accept meeting requests. Competitive offerings with lots to upsell within accounts across other departments and LOBs.. The products are competitive and sufficiently suited for customers' needs,
cons: It can be easy to get stuck in discussions about legacy paper-based services that customers know Iron Mountain for (offsite records storage and doc shredding are their bread and butter). While there is a big opportunity for converting these legacy customers to digital services, Iron Mountain has most room to grow in it's cloud, digitization, and digital storage businesses. Nearly all sales are generated within existing customers who have large offsite storage accounts already, by forming relationships with the right people to find new projects, expansions, and renewal upsells. Frequent account team changes and annual rep reassignments seem to have the most damaging impact to these relationships. Rarely are deals won from a position of clear product superiority or lowest price, but rather from trusted relationships with the customer's AE and account team.

pros: It’s a neat company to work for with a lot of talent to learn from. Pay is competitive.
cons: Rapid growth means most of the front line staff has been offshored. There are a lot of silos within the organization with aggressive goals that leads to conflicting priorities between teams. Certain parts of the organization can be very stressful. It’s easy to feel like a number. Benefits are not what they used to be.

title: Friendly
pros: People were open and friendly, management never felt unapproachable.

title: Don't join the company
pros: "Remote working" is the only pro-factor, but don't just join because they offer a remote work culture. They are doing so to cut costs, and you will not benefit from it.
cons: Biased culture! There are three different types of biasing going on in the company - 1) People who have moved from Neilsen prefer to work only with them. So even if they hire you, you must be their puppet to sustain. Your experience and education will not matter. You will only hear, "It doesn't matter what you have done before joining IRM." 2) People who have been in the company for over ten years. They have their bubble and will ignore your career, education, and experience. It doesn't matter to them. You will go back to the start of your career with the kind of responsibilities you will get (only transactional). 3) Ex-Neilsen employees are biased towards tenured IRM employees as they need their IRM experience to get things done. In this company, no one will hear your issues—no HR, no Employee Mental Health, No Senior Management, No Leadership, nada! If you can butter people and get through, that is the only option.

title: Awesome place to learn and grow
pros: I was recruited to join Iron Mountain a year ago. When first contacted I thought, "the shredding company?" which is a common misperception. Iron Mountain is so much more. Our Matterhorn growth and transformation story is awe-inspiring and to be able to be even one sentence of one page of one chapter of that growth story makes me feel like I'm having an immense impact. Not to mention the Head of Executive Search and the Head of Talent Acquisition are 2 of the best bosses I've had in my 20+ year career. They really know the industry and the talent function, and have the patience to impart what they know in a meaningful and resonant way. I am beyond blessed to have joined such a great team and am delighted to be able to help recruit some of the best and brightest executives to join our climb.
cons: The organization is growing and changing so rapidly that (1) sometimes it is hard to keep up with what each of the business units are doing which can be challenging when trying to tell the full IRM story and (2) there are internal transitions that are part of the growing pains of an organization undergoing this much transformation.

title: Great place to work and grow
pros: Absolutely love the team and the people and culture at Iron Mountain. If you are looking for a great place to work, when people respect each other, they value their team members and appreciate talent. This is the place for you. The senior mgmt clearly communicates throughout the organization, there is a sense of camaraderie and belonging for all employees. It has a diverse group of people from around the world and everyone's opinions matter at Iron Mountain. I feel like you can get heard and everyone is fighting to win customers - working towards presenting our best foot forward. Customer comes first and I love that everyone's always working to make this a better place to work.
cons: Like all companies there are always things that can be a hinderance in your work like the company is too big and sometimes takes long to get things approved or done, sometimes there are too many people involved or you don't know whom to go to for a resolution in IT. But that comes with any big organization. I also think budgets get shifted, but that is also normal elsewhere. I think working with awesome people overrides all these issues that probably exist in every company. I'd pick great culture over these cons.

title: Note What They Say it Is
pros: -Paycheck every two weeks -working indoors
cons: -Ask for way more work than they present at the interview or job description -Training is spotty and there is no consistent standard for the client that you are actually working for. This company is just a white label for another company with unrealistic workloads expectations. -They will periodically lecture you during meetings about not taking bathroom breaks on non designated break times. -Some supervisors will consistently ignore your presence when you are standing there with a question. You will always have questions. -There is not enough break time to use the bathroom, warm up your food, eat the food, get a moment of fresh air or make an important phone call all on one lunch break. You are not allowed to use the exit nearest all of the break time amenities so you will have to wall across a huge work room to get outside to your car or anything like that. -The system is so fragile that the smallest of mistakes causes a series of research tasks, searching for missing documents department-wide or clients not getting monetary transfers on time. -periodically throughout each year will come a time thar twelve hour shifts six or seven days a week for a month or more at a time will be mandatory, Overtime can be helpful but not if you desire to be with your family and/or pets and have enough energy to take proper care of them and/or yourself.

title: Mismanaged from the top

cons: Management is more concerned with checking meaningless boxes so they get their bonuses. They pay lip service to the driver's legitimate complaints, no effort to improve the daily struggles of the drivers. Horrible customer service and the drivers get the brunt of the customer's frustrations. You have to move to advance.

title: American Company with full of Indians
pros: $80 commuter credit per month OK pay package
cons: I recently had the experience of working for a company based in Boston, MA, with the Engineering team located in Tampa, FL, and another significant presence in India, encompassing various levels from management to Engineering leads. During my tenure, I observed some challenges in the organizational culture and communication, which I believe could be improved. Notably, I found the decision-making process regarding layoffs to be unclear. Despite receiving a high performance review (4.0 out of 4.0), I was unexpectedly laid off. This coincided with the company hiring new team members, which raised some questions for me about the criteria used for these decisions. For those considering employment with this company, I would advise paying close attention to the company culture and communication practices during the interview process. It's crucial to ensure that the environment aligns with your professional values and expectations for a supportive and transparent workplace.

title: Only people giving this place a good review is Management and above
pros: There are no good qualities.
cons: They work you to death and send jobs overseas. The only people you see giving a good review is management and above. Ask yourself why. They are probably getting paid to do so. They don't care about their employees at all. When I first started there were jobs all over the US and Canada. Year after year jobs went overseas till now there is hardly any jobs except in a center they bought that use to be another companies. I guarantee they will lose their jobs soon enough. CEO only cares about making his millions. He has ruined this company by buying out other companies to gain the monopoly. As an employee they literally work you to death and will keep adding more and more work. Companies including some very large companies are ending contracts because of the fact that they must deal with overseas sweatshops. Stay far away from this company trust me.

title: Excellent culture & collaborative teams
pros: I have worked at some of the largest and most well-respected tech companies in the world, and Iron Mountain is by far the best. They have a great work/life balance, and the work is steady and predictable. I used to work 60 hour weeks, with little to show for it, but I work fewer hours here and get more accomplished. There are so many pros, but here are just a few: Excellent pay and benefits package FT Remote with flexible schedule Global, Enterprise-level technology Training budget for professional development Tenured employees with deep functional knowledge
cons: No office to work in, so you really have to have a good setup at your house. We work globally, so there are occasional meetings before/after normal working hours.

title: Lacked Leadership Diversity. Leadership lacked professional integrity and maturity.
pros: During interview process, seemed very open to embracing new leader with new perspective, previous experience, expertise and success. There were some senior leaders who respected expertise and welcomed ideas, perspectives and effective leadership skills. Compensation at upper levels is reasonably competitive. Opportunity for cross-functional collaboration if you get "connected" with the right people.
cons: Certain leaders have privileged attitude and attempt to bully new hires. Lack of professional integrity and maturity among leaders was appalling. Allowing certain leader to go unchecked for their unethical behavior resulted in a very toxic, hostile environment. Taking credit for other's ideas and presenting as their own, sabotaging initiatives, false accusations, inappropriate accusations, falsifications of performance metrics were a constant with certain leaders but not addressed, empowering continued unethical behavior and actions.
